author: Ground News
title: Ground News - Family, West Stanly firefighters reunite after carbon monoxide leak - The Stanly News & Press
text:
Summary by Ground News A passing storm caused a power outage at the Oakboro home of Curtis and Anita Barbee. Their gas fireplace logs, a common accessory in many homes, malfunctioned, leaking deadly carbon monoxide fumes into the house. The colorless and odorless fumes triggered the CO detector in the home security system. West Stanly Fire Department dispatched to the home, found the three Barbees safely outside. Share menu More

author: Harvey Barbee
title: Gaithersburg, MD – Pedestrian Injured in Collision at Quince Orchard Blvd & Sebastiani Blvd
text:
Gaithersburg, MD (December 19, 2024) – A pedestrian was injured in a collision at the intersection of Quince Orchard Blvd and Sebastiani Blvd on Wednesday. The incident has sparked an investigation into the factors contributing to the accident.
Emergency responders, including Gaithersburg Fire and Rescue crews, arrived promptly at the scene to provide assistance. The pedestrian was treated for injuries and transported to a local hospital for further care. The extent of the injuries has not yet been disclosed.
Traffic in the area was briefly disrupted as authorities and rescue teams worked to secure the scene and ensure the safety of all involved. The circumstances leading to the collision remain under investigation.
Pedestrian Accidents in Maryland Pedestrian accidents are a growing concern in Maryland, particularly in busy urban areas like Gaithersburg. Intersections such as Quince Orchard Blvd and Sebastiani Blvd often see significant pedestrian and vehicle activity, making vigilance essential for both drivers and walkers.
Common causes of pedestrian accidents include driver distraction, failure to yield, and poor visibility, particularly during low-light conditions. These incidents can result in injuries ranging from minor to severe, often requiring immediate medical attention and long-term recovery efforts.
Victims of pedestrian accidents face numerous challenges, including medical costs, potential rehabilitation, and emotional distress. It is essential for victims to understand their rights, cooperate with authorities during investigations, and consider seeking legal advice to navigate insurance claims and secure fair compensation.
For more information or to receive help after an accident, contact Local Accident Reports. If you or someone you know has been injured in a crash, reach out to Local Accident Reports for assistance.
topics: Disaster and Accident->transportation accident and incident

author: Rob Moderelli
title: Dawes Announce Second Annual “Dawes & Friends: Christmas in LA” Performance
text:
Dawes Announce Second Annual “Dawes & Friends: Christmas in LA” Performance
Photo Credit: Jon Chu
Today, Sept. 19, Dawes took to its social channels to announce the 2024 iteration of its “Dawes & Friends: Christmas in LA” performance. Staging at Los Angeles’ The Bellwether, the event will unite the folk-rock mainstays–recently slimmed down to the two core members Taylor and Griffin Goldsmith–with an impressive rotation of special guests, tapping some of the biggest bands in the worlds of alternative and indie rock for a thrilling holiday get-together. The band’s second annual Christmas show will stage on December 7, and fans can expect more information on the guests to attend as the event approaches.
Dawes debuted their “Dawes & Friends: Christmas in LA” format in 2023, assuming the spotlight on Dec. 9, 2023. Through the course of the evening, the group–then also featuring keyboardist Lee Pardini–performed 17 originals and fan favorites from their guests, liberally sprinkling in Christmas-themed entries. The friends to support Dawes included X Ambassadors’ Sam Nelson, who covered Donny Hathaway’s “This Christmas,” Panic! At the Disco’s Mike Viola, who gave his own “Paul McCartney” and Dawes’ “Comes in Waves,” Matt Koma of Winnetka Bowling League, who shared his band’s “Feeling California” and his hosts’ “When the Tequila Runs Out” and Madison Cunningham, who performed “Broken Harvest” with the band.
The evening’s latter half saw a highlight with the arrival of My Morning Jacket’s Jim James and Bo Koster, who issued their classic “Oh My Christmas Tree” with the Dawes trio. The final familiar face to join was Simon Dawes co-founder Blake Mills, who shared his original “Skeleton Is Walking” before returning to Dawes’ roots with the Simon Dawes favorites “Lazy Daisy” and “Salute the Institution.” If last year’s show is any indication, fans can look forward to a star-studded celebration of Dawes’ catalog and community at their 2024 Christmas show.
Pre-sale tickets for “Dawes & Friends: Christmas in LA” are available now with code HOUSEPARTIES. For more information, visit
dawestheband.com/tour.
